sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Non-neuropathic Gaucher's disease, chronic (Mild to Moderate): 100 mg ORALLY 3 times daily at regular intervals

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment, CrCl 50 to 70 mL/min/1.73 m(2): starting dose is 100 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • renal impairment, CrCl 30 to 50 mL/min/1.73 m(2): starting dose is 100 mg ORALLY once daily
  • renal impairment, CrCl less than 30 mL/min/1.73 m(2): use not recommended
  • elderly: use with caution; start at the lower end of the dosing range
  • adverse effects (eg, diarrhea, tremor): consider dose reduction to 100 mg once or twice daily

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Non-neuropathic Gaucher's disease, chronic (Mild to Moderate)

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• diarrhea and weight loss have been reported; evaluate presence of underlying gastrointestinal disease if gastrointestinal events do not respond to intervention and consider risk/benefit of continued miglustat therapy
  • elderly patients; dosage adjustment may be warranted
  • peripheral neuropathy has been reported; monitoring recommended; if symptoms occur evaluate risk/benefit of continued miglustat therapy; discontinuation of treatment may be warranted
  • platelet count reductions, have occurred; cases were generally mild and were not associated with bleeding; monitoring recommended
  • renal impairment, mild to moderate; reduced drug clearance and increased risk of drug toxicity; dosage adjustment recommended
  • renal impairment, severe; use is not recommended
  • tremor, new-onset or exacerbation of preexisting tremor has been reported; dose reduction or discontinuation of therapy may be warranted
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Endocrine metabolic:Abnormal weight loss (39% to 67%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (18% to 67%), Constipation (8%), Diarrhea (85% to 100%), Flatulence (29% to 50%), Nausea (8% to 22%), Vomiting (4% to 11%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Cramp (up to 11%), Leg cramp (4% to 11%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (17%), Dizziness (up to 11%), Headache (21% to 22%), Paresthesia (up to 7%), Tremor (11% to 30%)
  • Ophthalmic:Visual disturbance (up to 17%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia (6% to 7%)
  • Neurologic:Peripheral neuropathy (3%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Miglustat functions as a competitive and reversible inhibitor of the enzyme glucosylceramide synthase, the initial enzyme in a series of reactions which results in the synthesis of most glycosphingolipids. The goal of treatment with miglustat is to reduce the rate of glycosphingolipid biosynthesis so that the amount of glycosphingolipid substrate is reduced to a level which allows the residual activity of the deficient glucocerebrosidase enzyme to be more effective (substrate reduction therapy). In vitro and in vivo studies have shown that miglustat can reduce the synthesis of glucosylceramide-based glycosphingolipids. In clinical trials, miglustat improved liver and spleen volume, as well as hemoglobin concentration and platelet count.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Systemic: Majority of drug is excreted unchanged in the urine
  • Systemic: Renal: unchanged

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
may be taken without regard to meals; capsules should be swallowed whole with water

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement, reductions in liver and spleen volume, and improvements in Hb concentration and platelet counts are indicative of efficacy
  • platelet counts; periodically
  • renal function; particularly in elderly patients
  • neurological evaluation; baseline, then every 6 months

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Tell patient to report any symptoms of peripheral neuropathy.
  • Instruct patient to report the development of new or worsening hand tremors.
  • Side effects may include diarrhea; weight loss; stomach pain, gas, or bloating.
  • Instruct patient to take this drug at the same time each day.
  • Tell patient to follow dietary instructions during therapy.
  • Tell patient if a dose is missed, skip that dose and take the next dose at the usual time.
